Deputy Sports Editor Henry Cowen talks to Ben Cox and James Freeman; two young sportsmen making their names in their respective sports of rugby and cricket (Thumbnail credit Kevin Pietersen may be a big name but he's the kind of sportsman Cox and Freeman play against regularly. The Nouse Sports Podcast

By James Bithell

The Nouse Sports Podcast is back. The team discuss great wins for the rugby and football teams and a close loss for the women's fencers, as well as touching on Tottenham v Inter, Man Utd v Bursaspor and Rangers v Valencia. (Thumbnail credit A game of squash was arranged to see who would be first to listen to the Nouse Sports Podcast. Image: Peter Iveson)

The women's fencers are York's only club in their respective Premier League. Jake Farrell was with the team as they competed in their first top-flight game and witnessed the narrowest of losses for the White Rose (Thumbnail credit The women's fencers came so close, despite not having captain Louise Highton. Image: Sam Newsome)

The Nouse Sports Podcast

By James Bithell

This week's Nouse Sports Podcast, a special Freshers edition, features discussion about getting involved with sport at York as well as opinion on England's draw with Montenegro. (Thumbnail credit The rugby team celebrate the arrival of the Nouse Sports Podcast. Photo by Justyn Hardcastle)

The State of the Union: York Sport preview 2010

Sam Asfahani is a busy man. Invoices for exorbitant amounts of money swamp his desk and he is in the middle of training a new batch of University Sports captains up to the standard required by BUCS. You sense that he wouldn't have it any other way

From Ben Lairig to Capoeira: Beyond York's more mainstream sports

York is not somewhere where you can play only the standard sports. From Aikido to Volleyball there is a veritable smorgasbord of sports you can get involved with; here we look at some of the more interesting (Thumbnail credit Canoe Polo is one of York's most popular minority sports and gathered quite a crowd at Roses 2010. Image credit: Sam Newsome)

Women's fencers prepared for Premier League

York's fencers warmed up for the season by hosting their first ever Open on Saturday. With 72 entrants it acted as both pre-season training and crucial fundraising, especially for the women's team who face their first season in the Premier League (Thumbnail credit The womens fencers start their campaign against Birmingham. Image credit: Justyn Hardcastle)

The Ryder Cup's Welsh legacy

David Ambrozejczyk, who has been at Celtic Manor throughout the Ryder Cup, details the legacy that the great tournament will leave behind in Newport (Thumbnail credit Celtic Manor, home to so much drama since Friday, will leave a lasting legacy in Newport. Image: lhourahane via Flickr Creative Commons)

The ever popular Monty must take more credit

With Europe's skipper Colin Montgomerie modestly claiming he didn't play a shot and thus wasn't too important, Jake Farrell sums up just how important good old Monty has been at Celtic Manor (Thumbnail credit Colin Montgomerie, whose claims during the tournament that he didn't care about the Ryder Cup on a personal level fell on deaf ears, was pivotal in Europe's Ryder Cup success. Image: Monster via Flickr Creative Commons)

Ryder Cup victory proves Europe's ever increasing strength

Sam Morgan argues that Europe's victory at Celtic Manor today is proof of both Europe's strength in depth and that fact that our golfers are now equal with their American counterparts (Thumbnail credit Luke Donald is one of the European players who helped his side to victory today. Donald, ranked eighth in the world, is one of the eight European players in the world's top 15. Image: Keith Allison via Flickr Creative Commons)

David Ambrozejczyk reflects on the weekend's on-goings from Celtic Manor and previews the final day as Colin Montgomerie's Europe seek to reclaim the Ryder Cup (Thumbnail credit Rory McIlroy will hope he can pick up a point tomorrow against the in-form Stewart Cink. Image: paprika! via Flickr Creative Commons)

More doping controversy hits cycling hard

With the 2010 Tour de France winner Alberto Contador embroiled in a doping scandal, Jake Farrell assesses the damage done to the sport (Thumbnail credit The headlines make it appear as if Contador is already guilty, but he protests his innocence. Image: scarlatti2004 via Flickr Creative Commons )

With the talking now over the captains have announced the pairings for Friday morning's fourballs, Jake Farrell runs the rule over their selections (Thumbnail credit Lee Westwood will hope that, alongside partner Martin Kaymer, he can get Europe off to the perfect start on Friday morning. Image: Eugene Goh via Flickr Creative Commons)

The Ryder Cup - The captains' picks analysed

Nouse's Ryder Cup coverage continues as Sam Morgan discusses the wildcard picks of captains Colin Montgomerie and Corey Pavin. (Thumbnail credit The captains' picks are always a pivotal part of the Ryder Cup. Padraig Harrington is one of this year's more controversial choices. Image: cmiked via Flickr Creative Commons)

The Ryder Cup could reignite Tiger Woods' career

David Ambrozejczyk kicks off Nouse's coverage of this year's Ryder Cup with an assessment of Tiger Woods and the possibility of him getting his career back on track at Celtic Manor (Thumbnail credit Tiger Woods, pictured here in happier times, might be smiling again if he can help the USA to victory in this year's Ryder Cup. Image: Keith Allison via Flickr Creative Commons)

The Ryder Cup is coming

The Ryder Cup is on its way and, as Jake Farrell explains, our sports team will be here to offer their views and opinions throughout the tournament (Thumbnail credit Colin Montgomerie, pictured here at the 2004 Ryder Cup, will hope to captain the European team to success this year. Photo: James Marvin Phelps (mandj98) via Flickr Creative Commons)

The Age of the Idiot

Sean Cole looks into the art of football punditry and lambasts the "generic brand of laddish tedium" currently on our screens (Thumbnail credit James Corden, the host of &quot;an astounding spectacle of guffawing witlessness&quot; during the World Cup is part of a new, and not overly popular, breed of football pundits. Photo: alun.vega via Flickr Creative Commons)

College Football preview 2010-2011

With the beginning of term edging ever nearer, David Ambrozejczyk previews the college football sides competing on the 22 Acres and JLD over the year to come (Thumbnail credit Ali Laird scores for Alcuin in last year's College Cup final, but which sides will taste success next season? Photo: Justyn Hardcastle)

Should we judge the accused as harshly as we are?

Henry Cowen investigates the allegations of spot-fixing within the recent Test match at Lord's and questions whether we are really in a position to judge those accused. (Thumbnail credit Mohammed Amir, here looking disconsolate having been dismissed, faces allegations of spot-fixing. Image: *TreMichLan* via Flickr Creative Commons)

"It was my hometown club growing up" - Luton Chairman Nick Owen on saving his club

Henry Cowen interviews TV presenter Nick Owen on how he became the Chairman of his local club Luton Town, and what the future has in store for the Hatters (Thumbnail credit The badge of Luton Town, the beloved club of Chairman Nick Owen. Image: eamonncurry123 via Flickr Creative Commons.)
